column18: 01/04/2003: An unknown number of suspected pro-Indonesian militiamen stormed Tiarelelo in East Timor and attacked a group of civilians with SKS and G3 rifles killing three people including a village chief. A fourth victim died the next night.
column97: SKS and G3 rifles were suspected in the attack.
column126: �East Timor To Dispatch Troops After Suspected Pro-Indonesian Attacks Kill 4,� Agence France Presse, January 6, 2003.

column18: 03/07/2000: 17 men armed with automatic guns and grenades attacked civilians in Atsabe, East Timor, Indonesia. Ten houses were set ablaze in the attack. Casualties were not reported, and no group claimed responsibility.
column108: Many houses were damaged from the fire.
column126: �Timor Militants Set Fire to 10 Houses,� Lisbon RDP Antenna 1 Radio, March 8, 2000.
column127: �Militia activities in E. Timor increasing, U.N. on alert,� Japan Economic Newswire, March 8, 2000.

column18: 02/24/2003: A group of armed man stopped a bus on its way from Maliana to Dili, and on the main road between Dili and the border town of Batugade. The bus was sprayed with automatic rifle gunfire from SKS rifles, killing one man and injuring five more. UN peacekeepers quickly swooped onto the area and secured it from further incursions. The Indonesian Government denied any connection to the incident, and also denied that any pro-Indonesian militias were behind the incident.
column39: Timor-Leste citizens on a bus in Atabae
column108: The bus was likely destroyed by the gunfire.

column18: 06/20/2000: An armed group threw six grenades at an United Nations border post manned by Australian soldiers near Maliana in the settlement of Aidabasalala, Timor-Leste. None of the soldiers were injured in the attack. It was suspected that pro-Indonesian militias were responsible for the attack.
column39: Australian soldiers deployed as United Nations Peacekeepers
column97: The peacekeepers were shot at and had six grenades hurled at them.
column126: �Troops Attacked in East Timor,� Nationwide News Pty Limited, June 22, 2000.
column127: �Six Grenades Thrown at UN Border Post Near Maliana,� Lisbon RDP Antena 1 Radio, June 21, 2000.
column128: �Aussie Troops Under Fire,� Herald Sun, June 22, 2000.

column18: 06/03/2007: East Timorese politician Alfonso Guterres was shot and killed by an off-duty police officer carrying small arms during a political rally for CNRT Party head Xanana Gusmao outside a police station in Viqueque, Viquedue District, Timor Leste.   No claim of responsibility was reported.
column125: The officer, believed to be a supporter of the Fretilin Party, fired five shots and fled the scene. Gusmao, who was in an adjacent building at the time, was not injured. This attack was the first of two against CNRT supporters in Viqueque on June 3 and the U.N. peacekeeping mission in Timor Leste subsequently increased its electoral security duties. One male perpetrator surrender to police on June 7 in Watulari, Dili (District), Timor Leste.
column126: �Gunmen kill activist at Timor campaign rally,� Agence France Presse, June 3, 2007.
column127: �1 dead after gunman opens fire during E. Timor election campaign,� Japan Economic Newswire, June 3, 2007.
column128: �Mob attack former president's motorcade in East Timor, 1 killed elsewhere,� Associated Press Worldstream, June 3, 2007.

column18: 07/24/2000: Anti-Independence rebels attacked United Nations troops in East Timor, Indonesia. Leonard Manning, a soldier from New Zealand was killed during the attack.
column126: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

column18: 11/02/2007: An unidentified group of gunmen fired shots in the direction of the former speaker of Parliament's house in Farol, East Timor. There were no casualties and no damage was reported.

column131: was shot 3 times and severely wounded as he was walking outside his home at Areia Branca near Dili
column132: East Timor at around 6:30am. The attack appeared to be a kidnapping attempt gone wrong
column133: and was perpetrated by East Timor Rebels led by renegade Major Alfredo Reinado. Two of Horta's bodyguards
column135: exchanged fire with the kidnappers/gunmen who were in two vehicles when they attempted to abduct the president. It was also declared that Alfredo Reinado and one of his soldiers were killed in the exchange. This attack as well as a later assassination attempt agains the Prime Minister of East Timor the same day was considered an attempt to overthrow the government."
column181: Attempted coup against President Jose Ramos Horta
column242: A rebel group led by Reinado approached President Horta in two cars, and as they tried to make the abduction, Horta reached for a cell phone. The rebels shot him three times, and a shootout ensued with Horta's bodyguards.
column243: Brendan Nicholson, �President fights for life; East Timor leader shot on morning walk in coup attempt,� The Age, Feb 12, 2008.
